title: Apple just named a new AI chief with Google and Microsoft expertise, as John Giannandrea steps down
excerpt: The move is being characterized as a shake-up, but was seemingly inevitable in retrospect.

title: One of Google’s biggest AI advantages is what it already knows about you
excerpt: The promise is AI that's uniquely helpful because it knows you. But the risk is AI that feels more like surveillance than service.

title: OpenAI desperate to avoid explaining why it deleted pirated book datasets
excerpt: OpenAI risks increased fines after deleting pirated books datasets.

title: Nvidia announces new open AI models and tools for autonomous driving research
excerpt: Nvidia continues its push into physical AI with the release of a new reasoning world model and other tools for physical AI.

title: Even Microsoft’s retro holiday sweaters are having Copilot forced upon them
excerpt: Microsoft has not one, not two, but three new sweaters available for $60 to $80.

title: Construction workers are cashing in on the AI boom
excerpt: "I pinch myself going to work every day," one 51-year-old says of his new supervisor role overseeing 200 workers at a data center site.

title: OpenAI just made another circular deal
excerpt: OpenAI announced an ownership stake in the private equity investment firm Thrive Holdings, whose parent company, Thrive Capital, is one of the main investors in, you guessed it, OpenAI. While OpenAI did not spend money on the ownership stake, according to an anonymous source cited by The Financial Times, the company announced it would provide […]

title: Apple AI chief steps down following Siri setbacks
excerpt: Apple AI chief John Giannandrea is stepping down from his position, according to an announcement on Monday. The change comes as Apple struggles to get its AI-powered Siri back on track after delaying its launch earlier this year. Now, Amar Subramanya will serve as Apple’s vice president of AI. Subramanya spent 16 years at Google […]

title: OpenAI’s investment into Thrive Holdings is its latest circular deal
excerpt: Analysts will be watching to see if Thrive-owned firms actually succeed in building long-term profitable businesses using OpenAI’s tech, or if the result is really just pumped up valuations based on speculative market potential.

title: Nvidia’s $2B Synopsys bet tightens its grip on the chip-design stack
excerpt: The $2 billion investment in Synopsys, which makes software and components for designing semiconductor chips, deepens their existing partnership at a time when analysts scrutinize circular AI-industry deals and warn of a potential bubble.

title: Prevent a page from scrolling while a dialog is open
excerpt:

Chrome 144 features a small change to overscroll-behavior: it now also works on non-scrollable scroll containers. While this change might seem trivial, it fixes an issue developers have been dealing with for ages: prevent a page from

title: A Sparkle Of December Magic (2025 Wallpapers Edition)
excerpt: With December just around the corner, how about some new desktop wallpapers to welcome the last month of the year — and the holiday season, if you’re celebrating? Our latest edition of monthly wallpapers has got you covered. Enjoy!

title: On Inheriting and Sharing Property Values
excerpt:
There are many ways to share properties, but what would it look like to inherit and use any parent property value on a child?

On Inheriting and Sharing Property Values originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

title: The Accessibility Problem With Authentication Methods Like CAPTCHA
excerpt: CAPTCHAs were meant to keep bots out, but too often, they lock people with disabilities out, too. From image classification to click-based tests, many “human checks” are anything but inclusive. There’s no universal solution, but understanding real user needs is where accessibility truly starts.

title: Design System Culture: What It Is And Why It Matters (Excerpt)
excerpt: We’re so happy to announce that “Maturing Design Systems”—a Smashing book by Ben Callahan — will soon be joining the Smashing Library! Ben’s insights and advice are so powerful, we thought you might like to read an excerpt from the book. Subscribe to our Smashing newsletter to be notified when orders are open.

title: Designing For Stress And Emergency
excerpt: Practical guidelines on designing time-critical products that prevent errors and improve accuracy. Part of the Measure UX & Design Impact (use the code 🎟 IMPACT to save 20% off today). With a live UX training starting next week.

title: Sketch: A guided tour of Copenhagen
excerpt:
Sketch probably didn't "have" to redesign its UI to line up with macOS Tahoe, but a big part of its appeal is the fact that it feels like it totally belongs to the Mac.

Sketch: A guided tour of Copenhagen originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

title: Keyframes Tokens: Standardizing Animation Across Projects
excerpt: Animations can be one of the most joyful parts of building interfaces, but without structure, they can also become one of the biggest sources of frustration. By consolidating and standardizing keyframes, you take something that is usually messy and hard to manage and turn it into a clear, predictable system.

title: Should We Even Have :closed?
excerpt:
Is there really a difference between using :not(:open) and :closed? As always, it depends. Sunkanmi Fafowora explains why :closed is currently not a thing.

title: The “Most Hated” CSS Feature: asin(), acos(), atan() and atan2()
excerpt:
If we have a ratio that represents the sine, cosine or tangent of an angle, how can we get the original angle? This is where inverse trigonometric functions come in!
